Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Expectation2: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation2: Cloud tops are rising quickly, and several pilots await revised climb instructions.
Story:
I glance at the clock on my monitor—ten minutes until the team meeting. As a colleague, I’m expected to show up, contribute, and keep the camaraderie alive, even if today’s agenda is just a routine catch-up. The meeting will be recorded, but I know my absence will be noticed. My phone buzzes with a reminder, and I sigh, feeling the weight of expectation.

But out the window, the sky is changing fast. As an air traffic controller, I see the cloud tops rising on the radar, higher than forecasted. Several pilots are already checking in, waiting for revised climb instructions. My headset crackles with their voices, each one relying on me to keep them safe, to make the right call in real time.

My heart pounds as I hover between screens. My team expects my presence and participation, but the pilots expect my undivided attention and expertise. I can’t be in two places at once, and the pressure from both sides tightens in my chest. I stare at the blinking cursor, torn, knowing I have to choose which role to let down—at least for now.
